												A massive new update (6.0) has just arrived on Steam and it’s pretty damn great.  The changelog[darkesthour.darklightgames.com]is 17 pages long. Some of my favorite gameplay changes:— 90 FOV, finally!— A completely reworked spawn system. It combines the best elements from spawn mechanics of Ostfront and RO2. You can select a spawn point by just clicking on it on the map screen. And this applies to MDVs: half-tracks show up on the map as spawn points. — You can select the tank you want to ride from the list and spawn right in it. You don’t have to rush to the tank as soon as you spawn and then deal with a crew of random players who made it to this particular vehicle first. No more waiting for tanks to appear or for the annoying “Waiting for additional crew members” message to disappear. But you can still spawn as a crewman on foot and join someone else’s crew.— Reworked stamina system and gunplay. You can sprint for longer, but changing stance drains your stamina. So doing the “whack-a-mole” thing by popping out of cover for a quick shot and immediately ducking again will tire you out. Dolphin diving — even more so. And it’s much harder to shoot when you’re out of breath: your weapon starts to sway.— All vehicles now have rider positions.— Improved hitbox detection on exposed operators of vehicles. E.g. I think you can now shoot everyone riding in a half-track as long as you can get an angle.— Ammunition is now included in weapon drops, instead of being in a separate pouch. A downgrade in terms of realism, but these were really tricky to pick up.— Wire-cutters and barbed wire that actually stops infantry, just like in Carpathian Crosses. — You can drop and pick up binoculars.— Windows users now run a modified RedOrchestra.exe that is “large address aware”; this eliminates crashes to desktop caused by the engine running out of memory.And in general, the game looks and feels a lot more polished now. There’s a gazillion of little fixes and visual improvements. I can only hope that someone will update some of the old custom maps to be compatible with the new patch. And the Darkest Orchestra mod.

												As you'll probably know, 'Darkest Hour, Europe '44-'45' is a modification for the original Red Orchestra, set on the western theatre of the Second World War focusing on the beach landings in Normandy, which is shown by it's content, map design and models. Content wise, it obviously expands to that theatre and period, including its weaponry, vehicular combat, mapping etc. It contains most of the same mechanics from it's mother title, with more added features.Personally, I have been casually been playing the mod for quite a few years, and enjoyed it everytime I give it another go, so be it with myself, or a few others. At this current moment, most servers and community input rely of the 29th Infantry Division, a unit for the mod which is known to be the main playerbase. I believe it has been active for quite a few years, keeping servers up for pubbers and members alike with a mature and friendly enviroment. Of course there is other smaller units which are always to be present, but if you are interested in such affairs, the Jackboot forums contain that sort of infomation, if that's your cup of tea.The original Red Orchestra is known for its realistic approach to the First Person Shooter, and may be a struggle of patience to regular FPS players. Aesthetic eye candy from such titles is not the focus here either, and will only be of interest to those of the period, and having the needed patience for it's pace. Quick Analysis.Positives:+ An alternative to Arma.+ Enough content to compete with Ostfront.+ Active units and clans to participate with, if interested.+ Atmospheric, giving a sense of realistic combat.+ Runs well on most systems.+ Free.Negatives:If you were to be picky, apart from some small animation and sound quality issues, the only reason you would dislike parts of the title, would be it's entirety due to it's mechanics. It can appear very sluggish at times, in terms of gun handling and such, but as said previously, it's aimed at those wanting a more realistic experience to the usual FPS style. Being a mod, it's obviously going to build on the original, not take away.In comparison, it is the best/ only alternative for the ArmA 2 Invasion 44 modification, if you do not have a 'beefy' system to handle it, and is easier to set up if you would rather play it casually. The public playerbase is fairly active currently, but will reduce over the years.Oh, and remember! You'll need to suck a bag of raisins through a straw before you'll get the 'Practice' mode to work.

December, 1944. - Belgium, Lutremange.It was snowy, me and my buddies were in a forest. On our way to occupty a lumber camp, that wasn't too far from our FOB. We walked through the forest, completely aware of our surroundings, with our hands and butts freezing cause it was too cold. It was quiet for a moment, until suddenly we get ambushed by Germans. Me and the guys dig in quick as possible, our pointman screams out "RETURN FIRE!". We clash in a lenghty firefight, until the Germans had gotten the upper hand with an MG-42. We were being suppressed and we knew that we had to retreat back to our FOB, we were all shaken and scattered around the forest. A few guys tried to retreat back but were shot down by the MG-42 before they could even stand up and run.One of the guys in patrol who was next to me popped a smoke infront of the Germans POV so they couldn't see us, he then grabbed me and said "Come on, we gotta move!". We tried running back to FOB, under heavy fire from MG's and rifles, we ran and ran, we were tired and exhausted. I took a hit on my foot causing me to trip and fall down onto the ground. The guy behind me tried to get me up before he took a fatal hit to the chest. I continued my retreat towards the FOB, a few minutes later, I found myself wandering in the forest, alone, no weapon, no ammo pouches. Until a German popped up infront of me, he aims his rifle at me, but doesn't shoot. We both looked at eachother, I stood infront of him unarmed and he was infront of me with his rifle aimed at me. From the look of his face, I could tell that he was afraid, confused and tired, just a normal human being sent out to fight. I take one step forward and *BOOM* I fell on the ground, bleeding out and slowly losing breath as I watch the snow cover my body... Pro's.(Things might get updated here)- Good looking HD textures, don't expect to much though, this isn't a game from 2014.- A good community.- Long or short but also realistic battles.- Almost realistic Wounding System E.g. some bullets doesn't end your life, leaving you badly wounded. Bazooka's, STG-44's, Radio Operator, Mortar Operator. etc, etc.- Maps are well designed and look good.- Tanks are also well designed, the best looking tank is probably the Tiger.- Different factions for each country E.g. Paratroopers, 2nd Rangers, 29th ID, Fallshirmjagers, etc. etc.- Game is trying to resemble tactical and realistic combat gameplay, so Communication and Teamwork helps to achieve victory on the battlefield.- Devs & the small community are still active.Con's- Only one active server which is mostly active on EU time, sometimes US players get on.- Game can be frustrating and hard for new players.- A few maps are buggy.- Lag spikes, doesn't happen often though.- Bots are stupid, literally stupid and don't function well in Practice mode.- Animations can sometimes glitch, when running or doing other things. But it doesn't happen a lot.- Some maps can be a slaughter fest for attackers or defenders.- Some maps are very hard for the attacking team.- Only three'ish countries, the Commonwealth (Britain and Canada), the US and Germany.- Voice acting isn't the best.This is a good and fun mod to play and maybe one of the best mods/games to resemble World War 2 combat in the Western front.

												This still remains perhaps the most immersive online WWII FPS I've ever played, with the only real competition being the now long-dev-abandoned Resistance and Liberation Source engine mod. The mechanics feel realistically cumbersome enough to simulate actual combat and reject most senses of arcade-style multiplayer where individual kills are your prime motivation. Balancing survival with securing/defending objectives as a team really take priority over your own rank on the team for a given round. It also forces you to really adapt to having to bear the burden of being a rifleman/grenadier when you jump into a server even shortly after the round begins, since every other role gets snatched up right away, and this forces you to really adapt to the teamwork-centered style of gameplay that the game demands. Moreover, for me individual confrontations with enemies really feel like they sometimes come down to simply getting the drop on an enemy, often by sheer luck, which makes the playing field feel pretty even once you overcome the initial learning curve (a German Grenadier can often defeat a Thompson-wielding US Sargeant at close quarters just by luck of the draw). There are no bunny-hopping no scopers zipping around the map ruining the immersion for everyone else, which I certainly appreciate. It also has the unique distinction of not every single map feeling finely-tuned to be precisely balanced for both teams. Since one team defends while the other is on the offensive, your team may or may not have a strategic or tactical advantage depending on the map, which is fairly true to actual warfare. This can be very frustrating at first, but if you're open to it, it does eventually force you to adapt your play style to work as a team and shift your tactics to engage the enemy at hand. I have never had two different rounds of the same map play out the same way, and I have never gotten a deathmatch vibe from it (apart from the unfortunate times DM maps that have been ported over from games like the original Day of Defeat and MOHAA are voted into rotation).While the build of RO that it's based on is now over 10 years old, the dev team has done a truly admirable job since resuming development in the past year or so. The smoke, explosion, ballistic, sound, and sensory (vision and hearing distortion and suppression from incoming fire, etc.) effects all contribute to a highly immersive gameplay experience. The map design is by-and-large really superb, and uses the engine's capacity for larger scale maps very effectively. Again, for a game that includes vehicle + infantry combat side-by-side, it avoids the pitfalls of making vehicles cartoonishly overpowered or easy to use.I tend to find the winter maps the most atmospheric and immersive, and this may be due to the fact that much of the original RO maps were set during winter and the textures, etc. lend themselves best to that setting. Some of the French town maps have a feel of authenticity that reminds me of the first two Brothers in Arms titles. I do prefer some of the previous versions of maps from before the recent revamping of development (Lutremagne being the most notable example), but on the whole the original quality has been maintained, if not enhanced. Overally, if you enjoy the gritty, tactical military FPS experience with a strong emphasis on historical accuracy and a good number of engagements and maps that don't appear in other WWII games, Darkest Hour oughta be worthy of your time. It won't impress you if you're used to the more glossy and photorealistic FPS games of more recent years and value this over more tactical/realistic gameplay, but if you can suspend that hangup and take DH for what it is, I'll wager you won't be disappointed.

												Larks and frivolity await those who try to enter the big top at the circus. Dare the ringmaster use those animals after that scandal? Will the clown's facepaint reflect the innermost thoughts of a damaged and troubled mind? Will the lion eat a child?All these questions are very good but when we get to the nub of the issue, they are irrelevant. Darkest Hour: Europe '44-'45 is a reality tv show starring Vanilla Ice. This show aims to recreate the horrors of the western european theatre of war via partying on the Jersey Shore. With ensemble cast members such as Joe Scificiccicio, Emily "Cut-throat" Furzenschieldfelmacher and Kyle Scudding the whole affair seems somewhat "in terrible taste". The recreation of the battle for Iwo Jima is not only rather inaccurate (There were NO Japanese Cavalry divisions that consisted of Samurai riding Panda bears) the makers also seem to have forgotten that this battle did not actually take place in Europe, a little known fact. How can I recommend something like this when "Big Jack's Circus", the local performing act, is struggling to keep the business ticking over? With a ringmaster who is going bald, a potent metaphor for him losing grip of life in general, leading a cast of performers who'd rather not be there with the zooalogical equivalent of a septic tank kept in the back for the animal sections of the performance one must wonder: How can we enjoy life around us when so few others enjoy it with us?What can one reviewer do in the tide of content that flows upon him? Is it possible for him to keep up with every single game without having to cut corners whether in terms of his product or his very own thoughts.... his very own mind?The worst bit of this is that it doesn't support controllers so jog on Vanilla Ice, we'll be watching some other circus.Or will we?

												Though this mod is buggy and requires tweaking by the user in order to get it to function properly, the Darkest Hour Mod is one of the best First Person Shooter games I have ever played. The infantry combat is like the base game, Red Orchestra Ostfront, in that it is purposely sluggish and difficult to shoot anything beyond 200 meters. Yet, killing a person with a sniper rifle from far away or blowing up an Allied tank with the Panzerschreck gives a very rewarding feeling. However, the greatest defining feature of the game is the armor combat. Depending on the map, there are various vehicles to choose from with most of these vehicles made by the modders. Plus the combat is immersive for when you are looking down the sights, you need to adjust your range by either moving your main gun up and down or adjust the sight to destroy a target at long range. These targets can be destroyed from less than 50 meters to over 1200 meters away from you. These features along with the small yet dedicated community are one of the reasons I keep coming back to play.

												Darkest Hour is one of the few mods for Red Orchestra Ostfront that succeeded well and did a great job and capturing the Western Front as it was.  I'd like to start off by saying that I've played DH since about 2009, that was the first time I got on. And back then, this game was more populated than it is today. Needless to say, DH is not dead no matter what people tell you. DH has always been low populated in terms of community and that is what made it special, a small but very tight knit community. Even back then people would fearmonger and go all "DH is dead/dying" etc. If you are living in and around Europe, then past 7PM and later during the day you can play this game. An estimated number of 55 - 64 players will be on the server (29th Infantry Division one) which is the most populated. So you can play this game every day and have fun. Darkest Hour is not for everyone, the maps are rather large, there are many vehicle and class types and it has quite realistic gameplay. Communications are always preferred, through microphone or general team chat. The community in general is friendly as long as you work with your team and don't behave like an a-hole. That threw me a lot. I can understand making the player conciously reload the gun with new ammo, but not force the player to have to double tap just to put fresh rounds from the magazine in. A lot of controls were messed with for no apparent reason, though I'm guessing it was just to make it "different". So many people tried to say on the server i was on that DH is more realistic than RO2, I call that a total lie. It's just completely screwed over the basis of the game it was modding on. I understand this is a mod and I appreciate the Devs hard work for it, but right now I cannot honestly recommend this game. I hope in the future when I try it again it will be a lot more playable. 												I play this game almost everyday (Under the name Harvey if you're wondering), I had written a review for it before but i am rewriting it since there is a newer version.this game is utterly terrifying, the combat is fast and brutal, the detial is gorey and gritty (Reminds me personally of Fury and BOB), You have to work together and know how exactly to use your class to win let alone survive, To win you have to fight dirty; Kill or be killed and kill with discrimination (Fighting dirty does not mean spawn camping please do not do that) I highly reccomend playing it at full volume if you're using headphones, the sounds are perfect, while some sounds for the weapons arent as Authentic as some claim, they all sound just like Real guns and opperate accordingly, The weapons are an absoulte joy to use, personally to me, There is nothing like emptying an M1a1 Thompson magazine on a Nazi from 7 feet away.The Vehicles are absolutely Awesome, When you Fire up a tank you can practically smell the exhaust, They take alot of practice to get the hang of using, they certainly require some balls espically for the Allied tanks, but the Boom of the gun is satisfying and hearing a shell soar past you is intenseLastly, the game is pretty active, ofcourse only 2 servers are occupied, but its not rare for the infantry server to be completely full, and for the Tank server its usually full on Sundays. the community is great too, nothing to be intimidated by, like with all games youll have the S'talker and the two players bickering about god knows what, if you ask a question about the class you're using you're likely to get a straight answer.Anyways, thats all i got for a "New and Improved" Review, I hope i have convinced you to try out this mod, I unintentionally left out some detials on how the game itself functions but im sure the other reviews explain such things.
